text:
For the next leg of our travels in Kyrgyzstan
(Кыргызстан), we made our way to

the Bel Tam Yurt Camp on the south shores
of Issyk Kul Lake (Ысык-Көл).

We used this as our base for 3 days and from
there, we took a few different side trips

to some of the most popular sights and attractions
in the area.
Here’s a taste of what we got up to:
Well good morning.

It was only a few days ago that we finished
our three day horse-trek and today we are
getting back on horses again.

For this half-day trek, we drove from Bokonbayevo
(Бөкөнбаев) to the Boz Salkyn Jailoo.

Once we arrived at the yurt camp, we met our
horses and set off on an incredibly scenic
ride.

So we have reached our first lookout point
of the day.

Over here we have the town of Bokonbayevo
(Бөкөнбаев) where we spent our first

night before we went horse-trekking for three
days and then over on the left hand side we

have Bel Tam which is the yurt camp where
we've been staying.
Yeah.
For the last two days.
Two familiar spots.

Yeah, it is amazing to get that perspective
because from this high vantage point you really
get the a great sense of the layout.
Yeah, the geography.
Of course we have the Lake Ysyk Köl.
Issyk-Kol lake (Ысык-Көл).
Yep.
Which is massive.
And there are our horses.
Update.
Update.

So we've got back on the horses and we are
going up this next mountain and apparently
that is going to be our picnic location.
Picnic lunch.
I love picnic lunches.
Really excited about that.

So yeah, just chilling out for a few minutes
here.
Letting the horses eat.

The second stretch of the trek involved riding
uphill through the forest, but once we broke

through the tree line, we were treated to
amazing views of the surrounding area.

The horses got a little break to munch on
wildflowers, and we sat down to enjoy a picnic.

And we've got um sweet wafers, cherries, more
bread, juice.
So we're well set.
Thank you.
Oh, and the dog is here for a snack.
Haha.
(Fire crackling)

So next up we're visiting Skazka (Сказка)
in Russian or Jormok in Kyrgyz.
And this is basically the land of the fairytale.
The Fairy Tale Canyon.

It is a Fairytale Canyon and if you look at
these landscapes you'll see why.
It is just like surreal almost.

The canyon’s name is very fitting as the
landscapes really do look straight out of
a fairy tale.

There are parts where the hills look like
they’ve been painted in shades of terracotta,

rust, and ochre, and then you also have natural
rock formations that rise from the ground.

It’s a really nice place for a light hike
and a bit of photo taking.

Alright so this morning we are visiting Manjaly-Ata
and this is a sacred Muslim site and here

you're going to find seven different wells
and people come and pray here and also drink

water from the wells just to treat different
problems and also ask for a miracle.

There is a really popular well for people
who can't have children so we're just going
to be walking around.

There is a path to follow and visiting these
wells.

While the water of the sacred springs may
be the main draw for pilgrims, for us, this
attraction was more about the scenery.

Narrow trails wind up, down, and around the
hills and it makes for a fun hike through
some pretty surreal landscapes.

Just don’t forget to bring some water, because
the sun can be really strong.

So this week we're going to be staying in
some yurts but first up we need to learn how
to assemble them.
Yeah, exactly.

And we've actually stayed overnight in yurts
before.
Yeah.

We've had meals in yurts but we've never seen
them made so this is going to be amazing to

see if basically being constructed from the
ground up.
Assembled right from the ground up.
Yeah.

And we're going to actually be able to help
out a little bit I think.

The yurt-building workshop was located in
Kyzyl-Tuu Village (Кызыл-Туу).

Here we met Tolosun and his family, who all
work together to bring the yurts to life.

Everything you need for the yurts from the
wooden poles that make up the ceiling to the

felt that provides insulation, is made here
by different members of his family.

So we're not doing too much to help build
the yurt but we've been given the task of
helping to decorate it.
Decoration.
That is important.

I like this it kind of reminds me of putting
ornaments on a Christmas tree.
Look at that.

And I'm dropping a few of them but that is
okay.
Sam the interior designer.

We also learned that this family holds the
record for fastest yurt-building time clocking
in under 10 minutes.

They did it a bit slower for us so that we
could understand and help out with the process,
but needless to say, they’re pros at this.
And this afternoon what are we up to?

And this afternoon we're learning a bit more
about Kyrgyz culture.
Yeah.

So we're going to see an archery demonstration
and also some traditional music and maybe
even some eagle hunting.
Woo.
There is a lot of cool stuff coming up.
(Speaking Kyrgyz)

Back in town, we made our way to Federation
Salburuun, which is a group focused on keeping

alive the tradition of eagle hunting that’s
been passed down to nomads for centuries.

Eagle hunting happens during the winter months,
but during the summer months you can attend

demonstrations to learn about this tradition
and watch eagles training with furs and hides.

Aside from eagle hunting, the group also practices
archery and horseback archery.

Last but not least, we can’t talk about
our visit to Issyk Kul’s South Shore without
also mentioning the Bel Tam Yurt Camp.

Not only was staying in a yurt pretty cool,
but we loved the friendly staff and the camaraderie
amongst travellers at the camp.

They had a massive dining tent where everyone
gathered for communal dinners.

The highlight was getting to know other travellers
and swapping tips and stories about Kyrgyzstan
(Киргизия).

And now for the last activity we couldn't
come all the way to Issyk-Kul (Ысык-Көл)
and not take a dip in the water.

That is true but one of us had to volunteer
and no one was willing to so I lost rock,

paper, scissor bet meaning that I'm going
to be the one going in.
Alright.
Let's do it.
Let's do it.
(Waves sounds)
How cold is it?
(Splashing)
Hahaha.
Oh my gosh.
That is cold?
That is way too cold to go swimming.
What?
Way too cold.
That is as far as I'm going in.
Womp womp.
Anyways, yeah it I tried it.
I tried it.

To be fair it is early June maybe if you're
here in like July or August it might be a
little warmer.

That is a little bit too refreshingly cold
for my taste anyways.

But yeah so that is basically a wrapping it
up here from Issyk-Kul Lake (Иссык-Куль).

We had a really good time and we're moving
on to Karakol (Каракол) next so stay
tuned for adventures from there.
